job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Comradery between RNs within the unit. Wide range of specialties. Potential for great experience with different modalities . Somewhat transparent with future vision of hospital
cons: Poor structure of training and education system. Poor leadership. Management consistently puts patient lives in danger by forcing RNs to serve in an area they have not been adequately trained in. Nursing concerns are met with defensive and abrupt responses. There is a feeling of "you're just a body and I can do whatever I want with you" between leadership and staff. Specialty departments are staffed with travelers or new hires due to high staff turnover and social media posts trashing these areas in addition to the manager. Frustrated physicians refusing to admit their patients there or perform elective procedures there.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Petersburg, FL

review_title: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times
job_title: Registered Nurse in Saint Petersburg Beach, FL
pros: The best thing is that the people that I worked with are like a second family. The teamwork on my unit was great. There is a lot of opportunities for less experienced nurses to grow and to begin the 5-year long process of really becoming a nurse. There's so many bright people going into nursing now as a profession and they are eager to learn. I really enjoyed helping them on their way.
cons:
I worked at the St Petersburg facility. It went through a lot of changes while I worked there. The facility was old and falling apart and this was an additional factor to overcome in order to give patients a good experience
There was never enough equipment and supplies. The nurse techs were underpaid and it was hard to keep good ones working. There was a lot of staff turnover. The covid situation was not well handled. When the facility was purchased by a for-profit company a lot of improvements were made to the infrastructure of the facility. However the working conditions were often unsafe for the patients and there were numerous employee injuries on the job. Staffing was very limited at times and at other times staff was forced to take time off. Newer staff members often had to do so without pay.

review_title: No effort to retain quality staff. Pay is not competitive.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Punta Gorda, FL
pros: Small hospital family atmosphere between coworkers.
cons: Staffing ratios are unsafe at best. Corporate puts profits before doing what’s right for patients or staff. Pay is not competitive. Lack of leadership. Retention of staff (quality staff) is horrible. If you move from a full time position to a relief / PRN position they actually drop your pay by a few dollars per hour even though they are saving money not paying any benefits. I had to laugh in disbelief when HR called be to let me know they would be dropping my pay to just over $31/hr since I was going to a PRN position (after working for Bayfront for over 5years and 17 years RN experience).....I was willing to continue picking up hours even though my full time rate at Bayfront was $4 less per hour than the full time position I accepted at another hospital because I really like many of my coworkers but after being informed they would be lowering my pay  even more it just wasn’t worthwhile.  Seems crazy they wouldn’t want to keep trained staff on as PRN to pick up when needed but they would rather scramble to hire seasonal nurses which they have to train and orient for $60/hr. It’s sad this hospital has so much potential for our community if corporate actually cared about people and communities.....sad truth is they’re willing to cut corners and sacrifice ethics, quality and safety to line their own pockets with hefty bonuses. It’s obvious why Bayfront hospitals in Florida have such poor CMS star ratings and have earned such a bad reputation.

job_title: REgistered Nurse ER in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Well rounded facility and opportunities to gain skills
cons:
Evasive about their 401K plan and matching (or lack thereof) upon hiring.  Upon multiple requests for this info I was told by HR I would receive info in mail.  Never received.  No benefits discussion as part of orientation.  Shows lack of pride in their organization.

There are extensive "cliques" within this organization.  If the staff accepts you into their clique then you should do fine.  If not, there is extreme, unjustified criticism, manufactured exageration of circumstances and degrading accusations.  If the staff doesn't accept you, they will find any and all ways of preventing you from learning and painting you as a poor performer, regardless of your proven career track record.

Certain management is too close knit with staff to remain objective.  Particular departments are extremely non-diverse.  Not that this is normally an issue or an indication of how a facility is run but my work environment consisted of approximately 95 percent white women mostly in their 20's and 30's and most tied to a friendship clique. Preceptor spending the majority of her time texting on her phone.  Being a male nurse in this facility was extremely difficult.  I have never had an issue with coworkers in any of my prior careers including nursing.  Be careful, if they don't accept you and you are counting on learning and gaining experience from them you will have a very difficult time.

Overall hostile and disrespectful work environment.  Quit on the spot after one month.

review_title: Stay away if you enjoy being happy!

review_title: A place to learn if you are willing to deal with the abuse.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: At one time Bayfront provided excellent opportunities to young RNs.  To this day it is still a good place to learn as they are a trauma center and support numerous specialties.  However, most of the benefits for young nurses have eroded to nothing due to cost cutting (i.e. the earn as you learn program is no more).  The only positives are that you can learn a lot due to the diverse patient population available and that the schedule is flexible, but both of these are true of most hospital settings.
cons: The climate for the nursing staff has become downright hostile.  Upper management is abusive in their handling of staff.  Nurses are routinely faced with patient loads that are absurdly higher than accepted safe levels.  Intensive care unit nurses are tripled routinely.  Floor nurses have 8 or 9 patients.  Nurses are floated outside of their specialty without concern, compassion, or support.  The hospital refuses to use agency nurses to fill staffing gaps.  They would rather save a few dollars and have a patient die or a nurse lose their license than they would occasionally pay an agency nurse to bring staffing to safe levels.

review_title: Don't work there as a RN
job_title: Registered Nurse, Critical Care in Punta Gorda, FL
pros: hmm, not much...the doctors are great to talk to and get orders from. Most respect nurses. Ipod touch to scan medications and round on patient.
cons:
This list is long. there is not a defined place to look at patients information, you still have to use multiple systems to look at patients information.  IPod touch is neat because you have portable system but I can't look at lab values, doctor notes, or previous vital/output trend. You have to use another system for that. There is paper charting and we still have to verify and sign every other on paper.

Staffing is joke, med surgery nurses float to a pcu level. On a pcu level you could have up to 6 patients with no free charge nurse, charge nurse has 4-5 pts as well. 

Management, haha they are too worried about threatening people and suspending them than anything. Oh don't forget let's test the staff to see how long a call light gets answered by going in patients room and telling them push the light and see how long it takes. 
Oh and pay is horrible, pays way less than other facilities for more work.

job_title: Staff RN in Punta Gorda, FL
pros: Some really great coworkers, easy commute, smaller environment
cons: Horrible CEO  who looks at both staff and patients as numbers not people, his major focus is on profit. While I understand with reimbursement cuts hospitals have to closely monitor budget but their are ways to be financially responsible without sacrificing quality of care......to me it seems fairly easy to make the connection between doing the right things for staff and patients, providing quality care and ensuring safety - all these things will increase numbers, increase profit and increase patient and staff satisfaction. Keep cutting as numbers go down ....keep sacrificing quality of care until nothing’s left. Bottom line you have to invest and put your heart in if you want the hospital to be successful and see a profit.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Punta Gorda, FL
pros: Nice nurses to work with .
cons:
Only 2.0 PTO per pay period ( Bi-weekly)
Lowest Pay I have ever made

Hospital will not offer their nurses critical need pay as incentive to work

No longer allowed to order paper with holes in it because it costs too much .
Calling dietary for patient requests is impossible since the phone is hardly ever answered . It's so hard to work here .

review_title: A lot of promises but little action in management support, promotional opportunities, tools to do job.
job_title: Department Director in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Bayfront has good and dedicated people that truly want to make a difference. Many of the staff have had long careers at the hospital.
cons: Healthcare is a rapidly changing business and requires leaders to stay on top of new trends and be reactive to needs and desires of patients. The current leadership is struggling to compete in the current environment. Capital is almost non-existent and expenses have been cut to the bone. Many Manager and Director positions when vacated are often left unfilled or duties spread among other management staff. Units are often closed for a day or more due to patient census and staff are flexed and sent home rather than be reassigned to save salary dollars. Too many really great people have had to leave for promotional opportunities or salary increases that reflect their job responsibilities.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Benefits were fine before takeover from CHS (Community Health Systems) now pricier. Employees were great and if you had questions they always went out of the way to help you understand. They're trying to make things better but after the house cleaning that they just went through it's too little, too late.. will be on the sales block yet again.
cons: Staff is short handed in all departments. Staff is overworked and some are grossly overpaid. The building is old, they only upgrade what the public sees, many places are known to have mold and mildew issues. Morale has gone south for quite awhile, no direction with little hope for a brighter future..

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Everyone is helpful and friendly except from the management or executives.  You can get great medical experience since you get patients with trauma or critical care. acuity patients in the critical care settings increase your knowledge and skill sets.
cons: Management is not willing to listen the needs of their staff. Management is totally corrupted meaning the people in it have positions due to seniority . CEO and directors overlook the flaws of directors, mid management just to make their lives easier. Human Resources do not report to CEO all the complaints/mistreatment received from the employees about the managers and directors. There is no room to grow in the company at all...just leave!!! Pay sucks too no salary raises!

job_title: Human Resources Representative in Brooksville, FL
pros: Not very strict, can come and go as long as you get in your 40 hours a week.
cons: Minimum pay and not allowed overtime or you get in trouble unless you are a RN. If your job title doesn't have a C in front of it then you're a nobody. They make you take  your vacation time when you don't want to so when you really do want a vacation then you have no paid time off.  The COO will walk right by you like you are invisible and say hello to the person next to you and never acknowledge you.

review_title: Working at Bayfront Spring Hill Saved My Life!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Spring Hill, FL
pros: The staff is fabulous to work with and to receive care from.  Because I came to work here I needed a  new doctor who requested I get a mammogram.  Turns out, I had breast cancer.  I had all my diagnostics and surgery done at Bayfront Spring Hill. I learned first hand how wonderful the staff is and I would not go anywhere else to work or receive care.
cons: I have a 40 minute commute.   I wish it was closer to my house.

review_title: Too clicky and immature without supportive management
job_title: CVR RN in Port Charlotte, FL
pros: The Cardio-Thoracic surgeon is impeccable.
cons: It is like working in a high school ICU. No advancement in technology. No one knew how to to recalibrate a PA cath monitoring system.

job_title: Therapist in Punta Gorda, FL
pros: Dedicated and competent therapists and assistants. Management has been more agreeable in supporting and providing reimbursement for continuing education and program development particularly in the out patient settings.
cons: Employees must beg for time off especially during season. The environment has threatening undertones.  Example: If an associate fails to appear for his or her shift when a storm is imminent, the  offender will be formally reprimanded in writing, and his name will be submitted to the Florida State Board for suspension of the professional license.  So basically, you get to choose between your family's safety versus your career.

job_title: ER RN in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: There are some amazing nurses there, and you can really learn a lot.
cons: Nurse to pt ratio makes for VERY dangerous environment for pts and for protecting your license. Teamwork can be hit or miss, tons of clicks and “nurses eat their young culture,” no real path to become a trauma RN (they basically have to leave), and management is SO bad, and a part of the “mean girl” like culture.

job_title: Medical Laboratory Technologist in Saint Petersburg Beach, FL
pros: There is lots of overtime, but only if you are on the right side of the fence. Health plan with no deductible at the hospital.
cons: Compensation is a little less than average. This year the company did not pay up their share towards employees 401k even when it is listed as a benefit in employee pamphlet. No opportunity for professional growth. Passive aggressive manager. If you have good academic and experience qualifications you will be denied advancement if favor of a cheaper, less experienced MT.

review_title: Poor Management and staff is okay with rude and gossiping among the staff
job_title: Registered Nurse in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: There are some fantastic Doctors.
cons:
Nearly always 8 - 9 patients plus students and new nurses to train, unprofessional behavior is always overlooked as long as they show up for their shift. Between mid 2011-2012 over 90 nurse graduates were hired, only two remained by the end of 2012 (the "nurses eat their young" mentality is ALIVE AND WELL here). If a manager leaves they may never be replaced as long as they can get away with it. If you speak with a higher up about issues with a tech or another nurse, they WILL tell them what you said, causing animosity which is left unchecked by management.
Often floated to units where you have no experience.

job_title: Staff RN in Brooksville, FL

review_title: Depends on the department, but overall a little behind technologically.
